text:
Amy Pollock (in classroom): . . . looking
at intermolecular forces.

So just as a reminder, on Friday last week,
we reviewed London dispersion forces.

Amy Pollock (in office): In the past, we had
traditional lectures.

You would have heard me talk for 50 minutes
and the students would have listened, taken
notes for 50 minutes.

We try now to have the students be more active
participants in the lectures.

So we give them a lot of time to practice
drawing on their own.

We give them time to talk to each other, and
we give them time to think about some of the

concepts instead of just throwing lots and
lots of concepts at them and having them figure
out the details of those concepts later.

Amy Pollock (in classroom): Go ahead and draw
a Lewis structure for a water molecule.

Amy Pollock (office): The students are trying
things.
They're drawing structures.
They're making mistakes, which we encourage.
They're correcting those mistakes.

They're really thinking about the material
instead of just copying down the words I say
or what I write on the board.
Pauline Mansour: I think the way that MSU does their gen chem lectures is very smart.

I like how all the TAs are in their own little
sections, so it's really nice that we're spread
out and the students have us.
They have their professors.
They have a lot of help.

Yuhan Jiang: Look, I'm from China, where there's
no TAs.
You always have questions and since we don't have any TAs,
it's just the fellow students helping out each other.
Sometimes it can be very challenging and suffering.
Yeah, that's what it is.

So I think it would be nice for us to also
have TAs back then.

Kendall Latshaw: I actually took the CLUE
lecture.
I ended up loving it.

I really didn't like chemistry before taking
that class.

Davina Spears: Being a chem major, after getting
through all the top-level classes, getting

to be an undergrad LA and relearning all that
foundation, it really solidifies a lot of
the things you learn in your final classes.

Amy Pollock: This class today looks very different
than the general chemistry class I was teaching
when I first started.
What will this class look like in 10 years?
I don't know.

My hope would be that maybe we could have
slightly smaller class sizes with maybe more

graduate students and undergraduate students
helping out.

So I don't know what it'll look like in 10
years.

Ten years ago, I would not have predicted
that we would be where we are today, but I

think this has been a fantastic change for
our general chemistry program and I'm really

proud of all the work that everyone who's
involved in the program has done.
